questions.text: What is the most common location of aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution: The most common location of aortic aneurysms is the infrarenal aorta.

questions.text: A patient is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm when an ultrasound abdomen was done to look for gallstones. He is otherwise healthy. What is the diameter of the aneurysm above which elective repair is indicated?
questions.solution:
Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥ 5.5 cm should undergo operative repair.

Indications for operative repair in abdominal aortic aneurysm:

  • Symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm of any size or one that is expanding rapidly
  • Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm >5.5 cm

Indications for operative repair in aortic aneurysm:

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding abdominal aortic aneurysm is false?

choices.text: Abdominal aneurysms are more suitable for endovascular repair than open repair
Most abdominal aortic aneurysms rupture into the retroperitoneal space
Systolic pressure is maintained at <100 mm of Hg in aortic aneurysm rupture
USG is used to diagnose abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture

questions.solution:
CT scan is used to diagnose an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture and to determine suitability for endovascular repair. If there is a doubt about the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm, USG may help in visualizing aneurysm but it cannot be used to diagnose rupture.

80% of abdominal aortic aneurysms rupture into the retroperitoneal space and 20% rupture into the peritoneal cavity.

During the initial resuscitation of a patient with abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture, the systolic pressure is maintained at less than 100mm of Hg (permissive hypotension) to avoid provoking further uncontrolled hemorrhage. It is maintained at adequate levels to preserve cerebral perfusion till the patient can be taken up for surgery.

questions.text: Most common site of traumatic aneurysm of aorta?
questions.solution:
Most common site of a traumatic aneurysm is descending thoracic aorta just beyond the site of insertion of the ligamentum arteriosum. 

Traumatic aneurysms may occur after penetrating or nonpenetrating chest trauma.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female patient presented with a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalp and face as shown in the image given below. On local examination, the swelling was pulsatile. On auscultation, a bruit was heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp and face is suggestive of a cirsoid aneurysm.

Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections among the subcutaneous blood vessels. They are usually congenital. However, in some cases, they may be traumatic. The superficial temporal artery is most commonly involved.

Patients present with a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp or face. They are usually asymptomatic and present to the clinic due to cosmetic deformity. However, some patients may have headache, tinnitus, and/or bleeding. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation.

Angiography is the investigation of choice.

Treatment includes surgical resection, endovascular occlusion or injection of percutaneous sclerosing agents.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm

questions.solution:
Surgery is indicated in an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) only if its diameter is more than 55 mm in a male patient. 

If the diameter is less than 55 mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55 mm.

Indications for surgery in abdominal aortic aneurysm:

  • Size >5.5 cm in males 
  • Size >5 cm in females 
  • Expansion of >1 cm in one year 
  • Painful tender aneurysm 
  • Thrombosed aneurysm; aneurysm with distal emboli

Management of aortic aneurysm: AAA is surgically managed by dacron graft repair. It can be either open or EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair) 

  • Open surgical repair is done by exposing the aorta through a mid-sternal incision and graft replacement. To expose the aorta the descending colon should be mobilized medially and this is known as left visceral rotation or Mattox procedure.
  • EVAR is a minimally invasive procedure in which an aortic stent graft is placed on the nonaneurysmal aortoiliac segment.

Complications following an AAA repair are:

  • Cardiovascular (ischemia and infarction)
  • Respiratory (atelectasis or consolidation).
  • Colonic ischemia.
  • Renal failure.
  • Aortoduodenal fistula
  • spinal cord ischemia

questions.text: Which is the most common site for peripheral aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Femoral and popliteal artery aneurysms account for more than 90% of peripheral aneurysms, with popliteal artery aneurysms being the most common (70%).

Two-thirds of popliteal artery aneurysms are bilateral.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the emergency department with complaints of fever and severe back pain. He is an IV drug abuser. CT scan of the abdomen revealed a saccular, lobulated dilatation of the aorta as shown in the image. What organism is his blood culture most likely to grow?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of mycotic aneurysm and it is secondary to microbial aortitis. The most common organism causing mycotic aneurysm is staphylococcus and is mostly due to IV drug abuse.

Symptoms may include hypotension, abdominal pain, pulsatile abdominal mass with concomitant fever. Laboratory findings reveal elevated inflammatory parameters such as CRP, ESR, and increased white cell count. A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the initial imaging modality of choice.

Patients require prolonged antibiotic therapy tailored to the culture and sensitivity findings. Surgical management includes debridement, revascularization, or bypass techniques.

The term 'mycotic aneurysm' is a misnomer as the aneurysm commonly occurs secondary to bacterial infection, and is rarely caused by a fungal infection.

Any major artery may be infected, however, the aorta is most commonly affected. The organisms infect the aorta and destroy the wall of the aorta, which may lead to an aneurysm.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of swelling behind the knee for the last 3 years. On evaluation, he is diagnosed to have a popliteal artery aneurysm. Beyond what diameter is repair indicated?
questions.solution:
Popliteal artery aneurysm repair is indicated when the diameter exceeds 2–3 cm, owing to the risk of thrombosis, embolism, or rupture and when they are symptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for operative repair of thoracic aortic aneurysm?

choices.text: Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter of 3 cm with bicuspid aortic valve
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5 cm
Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter > 5 cm
When diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm has increased  more than  0.5 cm per year

questions.solution:
Among the given options, the patient in whom the diameter of ascending aortic aneurysm has increased more than 0.5 cm per year, is considered for operative repair. 

Option A: Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter of 4-5 cm with Marfan's syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve is an indication.

Option B: Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5.5 cm, not 5 cm.

Option C: Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter > 6cm, not 5cm.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with a new-onset pulsatile swelling over his wrist as shown in the image. He was recently discharged after a one-month-long ICU admission for urosepsis. On examination, systolic bruit was audible and a doppler revealed bidirectional flow of blood. Which of the following is false regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Due to focal dilation in a vessel in which only the intimal layer is disrupted
Treatment includes endovascular stent insertion and thrombin therapy
Yin-yang sign is seen on doppler ultrasound of the swelling

questions.solution:
The patient most likely has a pseudoaneurysm of the radial artery due to repeated arterial blood gas sampling done in the ICU. Dilatation of vessel due to tear involving only the intima is a dissection, not a pseudoaneurysm.

In pseudoaneurysm, the intimal and medial layers are disrupted and the dilated segment of the aorta is lined by adventitia only and at times by perivascular clot. Pseudoaneurysm is most commonly seen due to repeated arterial puncture for blood sampling or catheterization procedures where there is an increased chance of arterial wall injury. It is usually pulsatile and systolic bruit can be heard on auscultation.

Doppler ultrasound reveals bidirectional, 'to-and-fro' flow of blood which is known as the yin-yang sign. Treatment options include endovascular stent insertion, ultrasound-guided thrombin injection, and surgical repair.

Note: A true aneurysm involves all three layers of the vessel wall.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is a known hypertensive for the past 7 years. His CT is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the condition is false?

choices.text: Men are affected more than women
In Stanford type B ascending aorta is affected
Pleural effusion associated with aortic dissection is usually left sided
Sensitivity of transthoracic echocardiography in diagnosing proximal ascending aortic dissections is higher

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing the double-lumen of the aorta are suggestive of aortic dissection. Stanford type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected while Stanford Type B involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery.

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. Predisposing factors include increasing age, hypertension, Marfan syndrome.

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. Aortic dissection affects men more than women by a ratio of 2:1. Pleural effusion associated with aortic dissection is usually left-sided.

Transthoracic echocardiography has an overall sensitivity of 60–85% for aortic dissection. For diagnosing proximal ascending aortic dissections, its sensitivity exceeds 80%. It is less useful for detecting dissection of the arch and descending thoracic aorta.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with a sudden tearing type of chest pain. He has had hypertension for the past 15 years and has not been on regular treatment. The patient was hemodynamically stable. A  CECT chest was done and is given below. What is the preferred treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Medical management with blood pressure control
Further diagnostic workup with transesophageal echocardiography

questions.solution:
The patient seems to be having an aortic dissection and CT chest indicates a Stanford Type A aortic dissection from the aortic root. He requires urgent surgical management.

The Stanford classification is used to separate aortic dissections into those that need surgical repair, and those that usually require only medical management. The Stanford classification divides dissections by the most proximal involvement.

Type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected. It requires urgent surgical management and may result in:

  • Coronary artery occlusion
  • Aortic incompetence
  • Rupture into the pericardial sac with resulting cardiac tamponade

Type B begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels and dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery affecting only the descending aorta. Medical management with blood pressure control is the preferred choice of treatment.

The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:

  • Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta (= Stanford A)
  • Type II: involves ascending aorta only (= Stanford A)
  • Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery (= Stanford B)

Further diagnostic workup with TEE(transesophageal echocardiography) or MRA (magnetic resonance angiography) is not required as CT is showing ascending aorta dissection clearly.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a double-barrelled aorta seen?
questions.solution:
A double-barrelled aorta is seen in an aortic dissection.

An aortic dissection usually initiates with an intimal tear. In some instances, the dissecting hematoma reenters the lumen of the aorta through a second distal intimal tear, creating a new vascular channel and forming a double-barreled aorta with a false channel.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on location of proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system that uses location of proximal tear alone. 

DeBakey system:

  • Type I: involves the ascending aorta and extends through the aortic arch and into the descending aorta/abdominal aorta
  • Type II: confined to the ascending aorta
  • Type IIIa: limited to the descending aorta
  • Type IIIb: descending aorta and abdominal aorta

questions.text: An AV fistula in the forearm is created in a patient with end-stage renal disease so that he can undergo dialysis. Which of the following responses will you not see when you apply pressure proximal to the AV fistula?
questions.solution:
Pulse pressure returns to normal when pressure is applied to an artery proximal to an AV fistula.

In an AV fistula, peripheral resistance is decreased because of which diastolic pressure is less leading to higher pulse pressure. Compression of the artery proximal to the AV fistula increases peripheral resistance leading to increased diastolic pressure and the pulse pressure returns to normal.

Compression of the artery proximal to an arteriovenous fistula results in:

  • Reflex bradycardia
  • Pulse pressure returns to normal
  • Decrease in size of swelling
  • Bruit will decrease or disappear

The reflex bradycardia and increase in blood pressure that immediately follows the sudden occlusion of an arteriovenous (A-V) fistula is known as the Nicoladoni-Branham sign.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for evaluation of peripheral AV malformation?
questions.solution:
MRI has become the imaging study of choice for the evaluation and follow-up of peripheral arteriovenous malformations.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offers numerous advantages over both CT and radiographs and has become the most important modality to diagnose AVM's. MRI techniques including time-of-flight and phase contrast can be used to isolate inflow blood supply to better predict the risk of ischemia following embolization.

MRI also provides well-defined images defining boundaries between the AVM, surrounding fat, and neurovascular bundles, which is necessary for the planning of surgical or embolic interventions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) presents with complaints of recurrent postprandial abdominal pain associated with vomiting and diarrhea. Abdominal examination shows no tenderness or rigidity. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postprandial abdominal pain in the background of CAD is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia(CMI). The most common cause of chronic mesenteric ischemia is atherosclerotic disease.

The three classic symptoms pathognomonic of CMI are:

  • Postprandial pain (crampy periumbilical abdominal pain within 30 minutes of meals)
  • Food fear (foods that precipitate symptoms are avoided by the patient and unintentional weight loss can result)
  • Significant weight loss

CT angiogram demonstrates both the arterial lesion and the patterns of collateral blood flow.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and stenting have gained acceptance as the first line of therapy for mesenteric ischemia. 

Nutcracker syndrome refers to compression of the left renal vein, most commonly between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, with impaired blood outflow often accompanied by distention of the distal portion of the vein. Most commonly presents with hematuria, flank pain, and varicoceles.

questions.text: All of the following are true about superior mesenteric artery syndrome except?

choices.text: Third part of duodenum is compressed
Angle between SMA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

questions.solution:
Option B is the false statement. In superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome, the aortomesenteric angle is reduced to less than 25 degrees. The normal aortomesenteric angle is approximately between 38-65 degrees.

SMA syndrome, also called Wilkie's syndrome (option D), is characterized by an obstruction of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA (option A) due to compression against fixed retroperitoneal structures.

Symptoms include episodic epigastric pain associated with vomiting. Risk factors include rapid childhood growth without compensatory weight gain, profound weight loss, abdominal surgery, inflammatory diseases of the abdomen, and immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta.

Abdominal CT angiography is the investigation of choice. The CT image below shows narrowed aortomesenteric angle in SMA syndrome:

Lifestyle therapy includes frequent small feedings and patients may benefit from lying prone or on their left side postprandially.

In some cases, weight gain or removal of a body cast improves symptoms. Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in few cases. The preferred surgical treatment is Strong's procedure involving duodenojejunostomy (option C).
